thread.title: Utah notebook: Booker, Hackett win weekly Pac-12 awards
thread.title_full: Utah notebook: Booker, Hackett win weekly Pac-12 awards | Deseret News

author: Dirk Facer
title: Utah notebook: Booker, Hackett win weekly Pac-12 awards
text:
Duo contributed mightily to the Utes' 30-24 win over California. Utah has now had seven conference honorees this season.
Upcoming Games Utah Football Utah   ASU @ Utah Rice-Eccles Stadium, Salt Lake City Oct. 17, 8:00 p.m. 4  Days   18  Hrs   39  Mins   43  Secs More Coverage Brad Rock: Whittingham looks the part as a natural fit for USC job Utah football video: No. 4 Utes looking to snap long losing streak to Arizona State Fourth-ranked Utes seeking to exorcise the Sun Devils USC fires Steve Sarkisian 1 day after putting coach on leave The 2015 Heisman Trophy tracker, Week 6: Booker vaults up the list after a huge night “ When you’re playing well and you’re winning those things seem to happen.”
Utah coach Kyle Whittingham
SALT LAKE CITY — Fourth-ranked Utah’s collection of Pac-12 Player of the Week awards grew by two on Monday. Running back Devontae Booker and punter Tom Hackett earned offensive and special teams recognition, respectively, for their performances in the Utes ’ 30-24 victory over California.
Booker rushed for a season-high 222 yards and two touchdowns, while Hackett averaged 50.8 yards on four punts.
The latest accolades up the team’s season total of Pac-12 weekly awards to seven.
“That’s a great honor,” Utah coach Kyle Whittingham said. “When you’re playing well and you’re winning those things seem to happen.”
Whittingham added that it’s great for both Booker and Hackett and that he’s proud of those guys.
Previous honorees this season include Justin Thomas (Michigan), Gionni Paul (Utah State), Cory Butler-Byrd (Fresno State), Travis Wilson (Oregon) and Hackett (Oregon).
WISHING SARK WELL: Whittingham offered his best wishes to USC coach Steve Sarkisian , who was dismissed on Monday.
“I know Steve well. I wish him the best,” Whittingham said. “I hope everything is able to work out for him. That’s really the biggest key right now, is for Steve as a person, to make sure he gets everything back in order and my guess is he will. He’s a tough guy and we’re pulling for him.”
As for rumors that USC may be interested in pursuing Whittingham, the coach maintained his usual stance on speculation about other jobs and declined to comment.
COACHING HONORS: Whittingham was named the Dodd Trophy Coach of the Week by the Bobby Dodd Coach of the Year Foundation and the Chick-fil-A Peach Bowl. The weekly award honors coaches from programs that magnify integrity, leadership and scholarship — as well as success on the field.
“It is great to see a head coach that has been so loyal to a university and program achieve success the way Coach Whittingham has at Utah,” Dodd Foundation chairman Jim Terry said in a released statement. “Utah student-athletes are being recognized with all-conference awards both on and off of the field and it is a direct result of his leadership of those young men.”
NOT A FAN: Utah offensive lineman J.J. Dielman , who is from Ahwatukee, Arizona, noted that he doesn’t really have any ties to this week’s opponent — ASU.
“I used to go watch Cardinals games when they played there (at Sun Devil Stadium),” Dielman said. “But I’ve never been a Sun Devil fan, never will be.”
EXTRA POINTS: Utah’s game at USC on Oct. 24 will kick off at 5:30 p.m. (MT) and be broadcast nationally on FOX . . . The 16 first-place votes the Utes received in this week’s Associated Press Top 25 tied a school record — matching the 2008 team after the Sugar Bowl win over Alabama . . . Boobie Hobbs has replaced Jordan Fogal as the backup at nickel back on this week’s depth chart. Fogal will miss the rest of the season with an undisclosed injury . . . Raelon Singleton has moved into the two-deep list at receiver.
